coredata.dc:title: Core-level excitation in argon clusters
coredata.dc:creator: Rühl, E.
Jochims, H.W.
Schmale, C.
Biller, E.
Hitchcock, A.P.
Baumgärtel, H.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
Argon clusters prepared in a supersonic-jet expansion are photoionized with monochromatized synchrotron radiation in the L3/L2 regime (240–280 eV). The cluster cations and their fragments are mass selected in a quadrupole mass spectrometer. The photoionization-efficiency curves of small cluster ions already show similar features which are known from X-ray absorption of solid argon. These solid-like features become more dominant when the cluster-size distribution of the neutral precursors is increased. The spectra are analysed in terms of near-edge features (NEXAFS) and extended fine structure (EXAFS). The NEXAFS regime shows cluster-specific features which are different compared to the atom and the solid. In the energy regime above 260 eV, EXAFS-like structures have been identified. Possible fragmentation mechanisms for core-level-excited argon clusters are discussed.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 178, number 5,6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 5April 1991 Core-level excitation in argon clusters E. RUhi, H.W. Jochims, C. Schmale, E. Biller, A.P. Hitchcock and H. Baumgartel Insti/ul fur Physikalische und Theoretische Chemie, Freie Universitat Berlin, Takustrasse 3, w- iouo Berlin 33, Germany Received 26 November 1990 Argon clusters prepared in a supersonic-jet expansion are photoionized with monochromatized synchrotron radiation in the L3/L5 regime (240 280 eV), The cluster cations and their fragments are mass selected in a quadrupole mass spectrometer. The photoionization-efficiency curves of small cluster ions already show similar features which are known from X-ray absorption of solid argon. These solid-like features become more dominant when the cluster-size distribution of the neutral precursors is in- creased. The spectra are analysed in terms of near-edge features (NEXAFS) and extended fine structure (EXAFS). The NEXAFS regime shows cluster-specific features which are different compared to the atom and the solid. In the energy regime above 260 eV. EXAFS-like structures have been identified. Possible fragmentation mechanisms for core-level-excited argon clusters are discussed. 1. Introduction Clusters can be regarded as an intermediate state of matter between the isolated gas-phase species and the condensed phase. Properties of clusters, such as geometrical and electronic structures and dissocia- tion dynamics, have been the subject of numerous studies in the past [1,2]. Mostly low-energy photon light sources, like infrared, visible, UV or VUV ra- diation have been used for vibrational or valence- electron excitation of clusters. Inner-shell excitation has provided valuable in- formation concerning the electronic and geometric structure of atoms, molecules, solids and adsorbates, as well as insight into core-hole relaxation dynamics and related fragmentation processes [3,4]. How- ever, the field of core excitation of clusters is less well explored. Only a few studies have been pub- lished on near-edge X-ray absorption fine structure (NEXAFS) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) of matrix-isolated or free clus- ters of metal atoms [5 10]. With increasing cluster size, the NEXAFS and EXAFS spectra have shown that the geometric and electronic structure of the Permanent address: Department of Chemistry, McMaster University, Hamilton, Ontario, Canada L8S 4M 1. clusters changes towards that of the corresponding solids. Argon clusters have been studied in the past by various spectroscopie techniques. Ionization thresh- olds of clusters and autoionizing states have been identified from photoionization mass spectrometry and photoelectron/photoion coincidences (PE- PICO) [1,11 14]. Inner valence-shell (Ar 3s) ex- citations into Rydberg states have been investigated in argon clusters [15]. More recently, optical prop- erties of argon clusters were studied by fluorescence- excitation spectroscopy [1 6, I 7] and electron-en- ergy-loss spectroscopy [1 8]. For given cluster-size distributions, both surface and bulk excitons were identified. From electron diffraction, multilayer ico- sahedreal structures of argon clusters were observed before the critical size for the solid-state fcc lattice is reached at N=700 [19,20]. The L3/L2 absorption of atomic [2 1,22] and solid [231 argon has been reported earlier. The atomic and solid-state spectra differ considerably in the pre-edge region because of different positions of Rydberg or exciton states. The lowest Rydberg state (4s) (244.390 eV) [21] occurs below the lowest exciton state (245.1 eV) [23]. Features occurring at 250 254 eV in the absorption spectrum of the solid have been interpreted recently in terms of electron-optical 558 0009-2614/91/S 03.50 1991 Elsevier Science Publishers B.V. (North-Holland) p9(atm) r* Na) Nb) 1 100 1 1 2 200 2 2 4 400 5 5 5 500 30 10 Volume 178, number 5,6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 5April 1991 properties of the surroundings of the excited atom [24]. In this paper, we have measured cluster cation for- mation after L2/L3 excitation of neutral argon clus- ters prepared under collision-free conditions in a supersonic jet. From these spectra, we have obtained both spectroscopie information of cluster absorption as well as evidence concerning the fragmentation pathways of soft X-ray excited clusters. Since argon clusters change at N> 700 into the fcc lattice of the solid [19,20] it was of interest whether small argon clusters already show the NEXAFS and EXAFS features characteristic of large clusters and the solid. Another question which is addressed is the occurrence of post-collision-interaction (PCI) ef- fects, which have observable effect on the Ar~ yield spectrum [25]. This question is discussed in terms of single- and double-ionization mechanisms with clusters. 2. Experimental The experiments have been performed at the elec- tron storage ring BESSY at the high-energy TGM-II beam line, which allows the dispersion of soft X-rays between 150 550 eV. The energy resolution (~S.E) is obtained from the full-width-half-maximum of the Ar (Lj 4s) resonance. Under typical experimental conditions, the relative energy resolving power (E/ AE) is between 300 and 800. The experimental setup consists of a newly de- signed compact molecular-beam apparatus. Argon is expanded through a 50 ~im conical nozzle at stag- nation pressures (Po) between 1 and 5 bar at T0rr 300 K. The jet is skimmed by a 500 jim skimmer. The expansion chamber is pumped by a wide-range tur- bomolecular pump (Balzers, TPH 450) with a nom- inal pump speed of 450 p/s. The pump speed is suf- ficient to keep the pressure in the expansion chamber below l0~ mbar during the experiments. In the main chamber, the jet is crossed with monochromatized soft X-rays in the ionization region of a quadrupole mass spectrometer, where the cations are mass se- lected and detected. The photoionization-efficiency (PIE) curves of argon clusters are obtained by se- lecting a given mass while scanning the photon wavelength. The curves are normalized with respect to the lifetime of the electron current of the storage ring and are divided by the krypton cation signal, in order to correct for changes of the transmission func- tion of the X-ray monochromator. Argon is provided by Linde with a purity of 99.996%. The sample is used without further purification. In order to relate the experimental conditions of the jet expansion with the average cluster size (N), we have calculated the reduced scaling parameter f * for argon given by Hagena [26]. F~ values have been obtained for various experimental conditions, such as nozzle shapes and diameters, stagnation pressure and temperature [26]. The reduced scaling param- eter has been correlated with various experimental results [16,17]. The onset of clustering is expected for f*> 200 [26]. The best fit for the N_F* corre- lation is linear for the high-cluster range with N> 50 [16]. In the small-cluster range, a non-linear cor- relation has been obtained in order to correlate the large-cluster results [20] with those for small clus- ters [27]. More recent correlations of N_T* show indeed a linear behavior for all cluster sizes [17]. Table 1 summarizes the stagnation pressures, re- duced scaling parameters and corresponding average cluster size (N) for typical experimental conditions. The onset of the dimer-cation signal is at p0 z=2 bar at T0= 300 K. This corresponds to [~*=200, where the onset of clustering is expected according to ref. [26]. According to table 1, one obtains N=2. For the highest stagnation pressure (Po = 5 bar at T0= 300 K) used in this study, an average cluster size iV= 10 or N= 30 is calculated. The cluster-size distribution Table t Average argon cluster sizes Nat different stagnation pressuresp0 calculated from reduced scaling parameters r [261 and experi- mental results (refs. [20,271). The experimental conditions for the nozzle expansion are: stagnation temperature T0=300 K, nozzle diameter d=50 tm. The corresponding dimer-cation spectra are shown in fig. 4A a> N F correlation from ref. I 161. b) !V F correlation from ref. [171 559 Volume 178, number 5,6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 5April 1991 obtained in our experiment is, therefore, well within the small-cluster limit. 3. Results and discussion Fig. 1 shows the PIE curves of argon (monocation and dication) and the dimer cation in the 2p exci- tation regime. The spectra of the monocation and the dication have been discussed previously by Eber- hardt et al. [25]. Below the L3/L2 thresholds (248.628cV (2P3/S); 250.776 eV (2P,12)) [2l],the spectrum is dominated by Rydberg excitations, which are known from electron-energy loss and absorption spectroscopy [21,22]. The Ar~ signal above the L2 ionization limit is associated with post-collision in- teraction (PCI) [281. This phenomenon also affects the shape of the Ar2~ yield in this energy region. PCI a n a u a Fig. 1. Photoionieation-efticiency curves of Ar~ , Ar2~ and Art The dashed lines indicate the energy positions of the L3 and L2 on,zation potentials in the Ar monomer (248.628 eV (2P312); 250.776 eV (2P112) [211). The Ar~ spectrum is recorded atp0=5 bar and T0 = 300 K. The spectra of Ar ~ and Ar2 + are recorded at Pol barand T0=300K. involves a recapture of the already emitted photo- electron after an energy transfer from the Auger elec- tron to the photoelectron [25]. The spectrum of argon dimer cation shows a con- siderably different shape compared to the monocat- ion and dication. The lowest Rydberg excitation (L~, 4s) is located at 244.390 eV in the atom [21]. For the dimer-cation spectrum, we observe a slight blue-shift of 0.3 eV for thts resonance. This blue-shift is lower than that for the lowest exciton state in the solid (0.8 eV), where the corresponding band is cen- tered at 245.2 eV [23]. In addition to the observed blue-shifted maximum of the lowest energy reso- nance, an asymmetric shape of this band is observed with a high-energy shoulder at 245.2 eV. This shoul- der is located at the same energy as the already men- tioned lowest Frenkel exciton state in the solid [231. It is, therefore, reasonable to assume that for a given size distribution of neutral clusters, small aggregates contribute to the maximum at 244.7 eV, whereas fragmentation of larger clusters into the dimer-cat- ion mass channel leads to the high-energy shoulder at 245.2 eV. The relation of the neutral-cluster size dependence with the cation signal is discussed below. The energy position of the lowest resonance in the dimer-cation spectrum at 244.7 eV may possible cor- respond to a surface exciton state. lt is known from Ar 3p excitation that surface excitons show a smaller blue-shift compared to the atom than bulk excitons [16,17,29]. The observed blue-shift can be also ra- tionalized by the potential energy curves of the low- est excited state of the argon excimer [30]. Above the lowest energy resonance, the ion yield for the dimer cation increases considerably. The shapes and energy positions of the cluster features are similar to those of the solid. However, in fig. 1 another resonance has been resolved at 247 eV, which is close to the energy of the L~ 3d resonance in the atom (246.927 eV) [21]. The absorption spectrum of the solid shows an unresolved shoulder at this en- ergy [23]. The following maximum at 248 eV has been assigned in the solid as an exciton associated with a conduction band of d-symmetry, because of the close energy position of the atomic L3/L2-o3d transition [31]. The following maximum at 250 eV corresponds to the spin orbit partner of the 248 eV energy feature. The asymmetric shape of this reso- nance in the solid has been reinterpreted recently in 240 242 244 246 248 250 252 254 Energy I eV 560 Volume 178, number 5,6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 5April 1991 terms of the influence of polarizability of the neigh- boring atom [24]. We do not observe the maxima seen at 251.6 and 252.4 eV in the absorption spec- trum of the solid. lt seems likely that the shape of the band B /D (cf. notation in ref [23]) is caused by coordination of argon in the solid. We expect, there- fore, a change of the shape in the large-cluster limit, which cannot be observed under the stagnation con- ditions of our experiment. The remaining higher-en- ergy maxima that were observed in the solid, cen- tered at 257 and 269 eV, are found in the cluster spectra as well (see fig. 2). To the best of our knowl- edge, there is no assignment given in the literature for these resonances. Fig. 2 shows the spectra of the dimer, trimer and pentamer cations, taken with lower spectral resolu- tion than those shown in fig. 1. The spectral features for the clusters are in agreement with the dimer spec- trum. However, their relative intensities change con- siderably. These effects will be discussed later in re- lation to the stagnation pressure dependence of the cation signals. t .0 cO t u t Fig. 2, Photolonization-efficieney curves of Art, Art and Art. The spectra are recorded at Po = 4 bar and T5 = 300 K. The features above 250 eV are not observed in the absorption [23,32] or ion-yield [33,34] spectra of argon atoms. They are believed to arise primarily from backscattering of the photoelectron from the neighboring atoms, i.e. extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS). In order to confirm this and to investigate the extent to which EXAFS of Ar clus- ters may provide useful structural information, we have carried out an EXAFS analysis [35,36] of this structure (fig. 3). Although spectra were recorded out to 500 eV, the oscillatory signal associated with Ar L2/L3 ionization only exceeds the noise level up to 320 eV, i.e. the Ar 2s region. Thus, the range of photoelectron wavenumber is rather small. Even so our analysis convincingly demonstrates that the sin- gle-scattering EXAFS model provides a satisfactory explanation for the observed structure. The EXAFS signal was isolated from the non-oscillatory back- ground with a two-section quadratic fit to the ex- perimental data above 250 eV, a weighted average of the L3 and L2 ionization thresholds, which is an ap- propriate origin for the wavenumber scale (k= [0.263(E E0)] 2). The signal between kmax=3.6 A (corresponding to 310 eV in the energy spec- trum) and kmjn= 1.0 A (264 eV) was used in or- der to have as large range as possible for the Fourier transform. The magnitude of the transform shows a t j n t u t o 240 260 210 300 Energy / eV Fig. 3. Extended-range Art yield spectrum recorded at Po = 4 bar and T5= 300 K, along with analysis of the extended fine struc- ture. The left.hand insert presents the background subtracted sig- nal after conversion to a wavenumber scale. The right-hand in- sert presents the magnitude of the Fourier transform which is the radial distribution function shifted by a scattering phase shift. Ar 2p 5XAF5 of Ar,, clustQrs k (5 l) R (A)4 561 Volume t 78, number 5,6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 5April 199f single peak around 3.6 3.8 A which is quite broad, as expected from the limited data range as well as the fact that Ar clusters with a range of sizes (N= 5 at Po=4 bar) contribute to the spectrum. Because of very low k data, the EXAFS was analysed using the calculated spherical wave phase and amplitude func- tions reported by McKale et al. [37] and by Rehr and co-workers [38]. An average Ar Ar distance of 3.9(1) A. was found. This value is slightly larger than the first-shell nearest-neighbor distance in argon ma- trices (3.7 A) and the solid (3.75 A) [7]. For small clusters, a larger Ar Ar distance might be expected because of their spherical shape. Coordination num- bers and Debye Waller thermal motion/disorder factors are much more difficult to derive precisely from EXAFS. Because of the very limited range of this data, we do not report these values. Higher sta- tistical precision spectra would allow a considerable extension of the wavenumber range which would al- low extraction of reliable structural parameters from the EXAFS signal. A complication which will need to be considered carefully is the correction for the 2s- edge and continuum signal. This EXAFS analysis as- cribes the first EXAFS maximum to the feature at 269 eV. The broad maximum located at 257 eV could be due to multiple rather to single scattering. The PIE curves displayed in figs. l 4 are affected by extensive fragmentation of the neutral precursors upon core-level excitation. We have, therefore, mea- sured the PIE curves of the dimer and the monomer at different stagnation pressures in order to change the average number of atoms in the neutral clusters (see fig. 4, table 1). For the argon dimer cation, the spectra show the same overall shape except for changes in the amplitudes of the (Lj , 4s) reso- nance and the EXAFS ondulations in the continuum which have been discussed above. This behavior is consistent with findings for electron- and photon- stimulated desorption of cations from solids. lt has been found for molecular species that the spectral shape of desorbing species from a solid mimics the gas-phase photoabsorption spectrum or total elec- tron yield of the solid [39]. This observation is usu- ally interpreted on the basis of the Knotek Feibel- man mechanism for electron-stimulated desorption [40,41]. In this model, the Auger decay of the core- hole is followed by a desorption process, where en- ergy conservation is given for both steps. The Auger Energy / eV a a ~0 2~. a u a B(a) I -..- I I. I a a 5 Cs >~ a u a o 240 242 244 246 248 250 252 254 Energy I eV Fig. 4. (A) Argon dimer-cation signal Ar~ at different stagna- tion pressures Po and T0= 300 K: (a) po 5 bar, (b) Po 3.4 bar, (c)p0= 2 bar, (B) Argon cation signal Ar~ at (a) Po=S bar and (b) Pc 1 bar. Contributions of argon ctusters to the Ar~ ion yield are indicated in spectrum (a) by the corresponding Ar~ spec- trum (dashed curve). (b) 562 Volume 178, number 5,6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 5April l99t decay leads either to one-hole states (1h) where an- other electron may be excited (1h, le), or two-hole states with or without spectator (2h; 2h, le). Two- hole states lead predominantly to charge separation if both charges cannot be stabilized. This is usually the case for most molecular systems and small clus- ters. The rapid Coulomb explosion leads to singly charged fragments with or without evaporation of neutrals before or after the charge-separation step [42,43]. For argon clusters, we observe that the absorption behavior of solid argon is reflected in the spectra of the ionic products, besides the low-energy features below the L3/L2 ionization limit. From this, two dif- ferent fragmentation pathways can be distinguished: Firstly, below the L3/L2 ionization limit, single ion- ization will contribute to the ion yield, reflecting the absorption of the neutral clusters which is different from that of either the atom or the solid. Molecular cations will be formed according to results from va- lence-shell ionization of clusters. The considerable amount of binding energy (1.25 eV [44]) leads to substantial evaporation of neutrals [45]. Secondly, extensive fragmentation via two-hole states occurs above the L3/L2 ionization limit. The doubly charged clusters will decay rapidly into singly charged frag- ments. The small size of clusters produced in the jet expansion is not sufficient to stabilize cluster diea- tions. Extensive fragmentation contributes also to the monomer-cation channel (Art, in/z=40). Fig. 4B shows the PIE curve of Ar~ at two different stag- nation pressures (Po 1 bar and Po=5 bar at T0= 300 K). At low stagnation pressure (sso= 1 bar), no clus- tering occurs because of the low reduced scaling pa- rameter (F*= 100). The spectrum is identical with that published by Eberhardt et al. under effusive jet conditions using the same monochromator [25]. At high stagnation pressure, the PIE curve of Ar~ can be formed by single ionization of unclustered atomic argon, single ionization and dissociative double ion- ization of clusters with and without evaporation of neutrals. Since the overall shape of the Ar~ curve is almost identical with that recorded under effusive beam conditions, it is reasonable to assume that most of the Ar~ signal is due to single ionization of un- clustered atomic argon. As a result of cluster frag- mentation, the ion intensity for the Ar~ mass chan ne! is increased relatively to the monocation under effusive jet conditions above 250 eV. In this energy regime, the ion intensity for the monocation under effusive jet conditions reaches almost the level of the pre-edge region. From the spectrum, the contribu- tion of about 10% of cluster fragmentation is esti- mated using the dimer-cation spectrum for subtrac- tion. This assumption is justified because of the similar spectral behavior of small clusters. This find- ing also shows that singly charged atomic fragments are efficiently formed upon cluster ionization. Es- pecially for the regime above 250 eV, we expect that dissociative double ionization of argon clusters con- tributes to the Ar~ yield. In order to prove this as- sumption, we will investigate the fragmentation pathways of argon clusters after L3/L2 excitation in a forthcoming ion ion coincidence experiment. ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Institut für Physikalische und Theoretische Chemie, Freie Universität Berlin, Takustrasse 3, W-1000 Berlin 33, Germany

ce:footnote.ce:note-para: Permanent address: Department of Chemistry, McMaster University, Hamilton, Ontario, Canada L8S 4M1.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Argon clusters prepared in a supersonic-jet expansion are photoionized with monochromatized synchrotron radiation in the L3/L2 regime (240–280 eV). The cluster cations and their fragments are mass selected in a quadrupole mass spectrometer. The photoionization-efficiency curves of small cluster ions already show similar features which are known from X-ray absorption of solid argon. These solid-like features become more dominant when the cluster-size distribution of the neutral precursors is increased. The spectra are analysed in terms of near-edge features (NEXAFS) and extended fine structure (EXAFS). The NEXAFS regime shows cluster-specific features which are different compared to the atom and the solid. In the energy regime above 260 eV, EXAFS-like structures have been identified. Possible fragmentation mechanisms for core-level-excited argon clusters are discussed.

sb:title.sb:maintitle: Structure and dynamics of weakly bound molecular complexes
Electronic excitations in condensed rare gases
X-ray absorption: principles, techniques and application of EXAFS and XANES
Intern. J. Mass Spectrom. Ion Processes
